any one player has entirely too much power to ruin someones good time at the drop of a hat

still absolutely no protection against getting matched with someone far outranking you.

This game is excellent with Solo or 4-man Co-op; however, there is a lot of randomnesses involved in this game, like being tunneled, unlucky totem placement, or not getting the right perk from blood web. I played both Survivor and Killer, and I think this game is good to pass the time; however, it can be frustrating to play either side.

Die Idee hinter dem spiel finde ich echt gut und auch gut umgesetzt. Allerdings ist es als alleiniger Killer auf der ein oder anderen Map schon extrem schwer zu gewinnen. Manche Killer können sich unsichtbar machen, dass ist etwas unfair. Man hört sie dann auch nicht.

Ce jeu est vraiment bon, déjà le principe d'un jeu asymétrique qui fait s'affronter d'un coté une équipe de 4 joueurs (survivant) et de l'autre un seul joueur (tueur).
Le but est pour les survivants de finir 5 générateurs sur les 7 disponibles sur la maps puis de sortir par les portes!
Le but pour le tueur est d'accrocher les survivants pour qu'ils soient offert à l'entité.
Le jeu est fun malgré un équilibrage pas forcément bon. Pour faire simple les survivants sont clairement avantagés à haut niveau (ce n'est pas de la rage car je suis moi même main survivant) et avec un vocal c'est encore pire! Mais les tueurs peuvent ce défendre avec des techniques qui deviennent normal à haut niveau ; mais pas compris au plus bas level. Car si en tant que tueur tu chasses un survivant trop longtemps les autres en profitent pour faire des générateurs (logique c'est le principe du jeu). Mais si tu te fais GenRush (si les survivants rush les générateurs) et que tu es toujours en chasse à ce moment précis alors tu perd de ton précieux temps!
Les bons points:
- Un gameplay sympa que ce soit en tueur ou en survivant 
- Des personnages tirés de films tel que Freddy, Mayers , etc. 
- Pas mal de skins achetable (dont un pass a la fortnite)
- Les tueurs qui ont chacun leurs propre gameplay (téléportation, lancé de hache, harpon, ect)
- Un jeux avec un GROS SkillCap
- Des maps diverse et varié 
- Des capacités qui peuvent changer ta manière de joué
Les mauvais points:
- On voit souvent les mêmes capacités à haut level
- Des tueurs BIEN trop faible par rapport a d'autres 
- Une Commu toxic malgré une commu Twitch très bonne 
- Un MMR (système de matchmaking) pas forcément bon ...
- La connexion varie avec la connexion du tueur (donc on remercie souvent les joueurs russe)
- Le soir pour trouver une partie en survivants c'est un peu long 
- Un system de level de perso qui faut comprendre 

Bref pour moi ce jeu est très bien malgré certains soucis dont nous nous serions bien passé! Mais si DBD est rageant à certains moments il est tout autant gratifiant quand on fait de jolies moov!
Pour moi à avoir mais on sait ce que l'on prend ! 
Tips survivants commence par claudette elle peut s'autoHeal!!

Would recommend this game as it challenges a survivor and killers mindset to think outside the box especially going against a good group of survivors or killer. it a game that gets better the more you play it as you start to learn more and become better with your skills.

INTRO
This is... not a bad game per se, and yet it has several persisting problems that mean I would probably recommend most people not bother playing it. I'll break down some aspects of the game, including what it is, the good, and the bad, and the game's current state at the time of writing.

WHAT IT IS
Dead by Daylight is a 4 v 1 online multiplayer game. 4 players team up as survivors, and 1 person plays the killer. You can choose which side you join when you queue, or you can make a custom unranked game and invite friends. You then choose your character, and choose various perks to equip (these are passives with a multitude of effects), and if you're a survivor, you may have items to equip like a toolbox or medkit. The survivors objective is to repair 5 of the generators on the map (there's usually 7 I think), then go to one of the two exit gates and work the lever long enough til the gate is open, and then to escape. The killers objective is NOT to kill the survivors, oddly enough, but get a hit or two on one to knock them down, then pick them up and carry them to a sacrificial hook (this is part of the game's lore). If the killer hooks a survivor, they can be rescued by others, and the killer's job is to go look for more to hook. This continues until the killer hooks all survivors at once, or hooks each survivor enough times that they're immediately sacrificed and out of the game (max of 3 hooks per survivor).  This is also where the first of my problems begin, but we'll get to that soon enough.

Sound reasonable? Perhaps it does, in principle. Each killer has a unique power to assist them, as well as their own perks and add-ons which can make them more effecive or change how they play. Some are easy to learn, some not. Some are also licensed, and these ones have to be paid for with real money (e.g. pyramid head, Mike Myers, Freddie Krueger etc). The rest can be earned in-game if you have a LOT of time to put into it, or also bought with real money if not (a bit cheaper than the licensed ones I think).

GAMEPLAY:

Core Survivor gameplay goes like this: 

* Go to a generator. Do you hear the warning heartbeat sound telling you that the killer is nearby? If so, carefully sneak away to another generator and work there. If not, start fixing. 

* Fix generator. If a team-mate gets downed or hooked, consider rescuing them, depending if you know how far they are and how risky it is, and how close to being done your generator is. When done, go do another.

* When 5 generators are fixed, go to the gate levers and hold that til the gate's open.

* If you get found, just run and waste the killer's time with "looping" (running around the same obstacles in a way that makes it difficult for the killer to catch up), using pallets wisely, and using vaults where appropriate. The heartbeat and red light that emits from the killers face in a cone tells you how close they are and if they're coming around a corner, so these let you know where to run somewhat. Waste as much of the killers time as possible so that your teammates can do other essential thing uninterrupted, like heal each other or repair the generators.

Core Killer gameplay:

* Look at where the generators are and make an educated guess as to which generators might have survivors nearby, and head in that direction. Trying to be sneaky as the killer is mostly pretty pointless as most killers are large, can't crouch, and all of them give the telltale heartbeat warning and red light cone.

* If you find a survivor, chase after them, maybe using whatever power you have to find them or make a chase easier. The survivor will of course try to waste as much of your time as possible so that the others can get the generators done. If you get into attack range, do an attack. Providing it hits and they haven't run a circle around you during your swing (known as 360'ing) to make you miss, your vision is now shaking and bloody for a sec, and the survivor gets a speed boost to run away from you. Now you choose whether to keep chasing for a second hit to down them (assuming you didn't have an attack to insta-down them, which most killers don't), or do you now break off and look for another, leaving them injured but able to move just as fast and get healed by their teammates when they find safety? Depends on many factors. You can also damage a generator that's been partially repaired by kicking it, making it lose progress over time until repairs are started again.

* If you hit an injured one a second time, they're now downed. You can leave them and look for another one if you think there's one nearby (called "slugging" in the community), or do what you're supposed to do and pick them up and carry them to hook, hoping they won't break free or have that one perk that a LOT have ready that lets them do an attack on you when being carried to break free and run off while you're stuck stunned for a few seconds, rending everything you've done in that second chase pointless and wasting potentially a large chunk of your time.

* Assuming you've hooked a survivor, you now go look for another to start the process again. While you're doing this, chances are that a survivor will come and rescue their teammate from the hook. Remember, there are 4 survivors, so even if you hook one and find another on their way, that's still two able to go and save them. This wouldn't be too bad, except for the next thing.

* If a survivor is rescued quickly enough (the timer is pretty long if they don't struggle to break free, which has little chance of working anyways), they now require hooking again. If they're rescued quickly enough a second time, then a third hooking is instant death, removing that survivor from the game (they can spectate their teammates I think.

* Hook all survivors at once, or all survivors enough times, to sacrifice them all and win the game.

PROBLEMS:

So, why do I recommend against the game? I've almost exclusively played as a killer, and I have to say... the game seems stacked against you when you're the killer, which seems... counter-intuitive. It advertises itself as a horror game, but it's really not. If what I wrote above seems balanced to you, let me explain my reasoning as to why I think it isn't.

* FOV: The survivors play in third person mode with a wide FOV. The Killer is in first-person mode with an FOV of 87 degrees, and this can only be changed with a perk that goes up to I think an extra 10 degrees at max. I can get why this was a design choice (the dev's wanted the killer to have "tunnel-vision on a survivor"), but this means the game is going to be unplayable for some people as killer. People who get headaches or motion sickness from low FOV settings are advised not to play killer at all, if you want to play this game. Minus points for small imbalance and lack of accessibility on this one.

* Theme vs Gameplay: The game advertises itself as a kind of horror game. It's not. Very rarely will you encounter survivors who play as if they're scared of you, unless you're much, much better than they are. Even then, you will still encounter players who literally follow you around when you're carrying someone, players who wait behind points they think are safe and click a flashlight on and off, or teabag in front of you, players who deliberately try and get you to chase them to distract you from their less capable teammates etc. While the latter is strategically sound, it doesn't exactly play into the theme of the game. All of this making supposedly scary killers into the equivalent of the old man annoyed at some kids for making rude gestures and calling them names... which, now that I think about it, is probably what you're playing against when this happens. You're the old man, telling the durn kids to get off your lawn. They don't though, they just insult you and make a mess of the place, all the while acting like it's your fault. Which leads into my next complaint...

Como amante del género Terror / Horror puedo valorar este juego al máximo, es muy similar a las películas.
El juego tiene un motor de gráficos versátil, su jugabilidad es sencilla, incluye grandes personajes de películas de terror clásicas, también de series de televisión, puedes jugar con ellos o contra ellos.
Cada partida es diferente pues te toca compartir con otras personas reales que juegan de distintas maneras.
En el Rol de Superviviente debes trabajar en equipo (Cooperación), tratar de jugar de la manera mas inteligente posible para lograr un buen desempeño (con solo esto logras subir de nivel) así como su principal objetivo que es sobrevivir y escapar.
De Asesino tienes un gran reto, ser despiadado contra cuatro jugadores del mundo que huyen de tí, esto puede llegar a producirte una enorme ansiedad cuando tú eres quien tiene las "Mayores ventajas". 
Sin duda, altamente recomendado.
